metadata.case_name: Unikat Sankunni Menon v. State of Rajasthan

facts.text: Appellant Unikat Sankunni Menon was in service of Rajasthan Government in Secretariat after Rajasthan constituted as State.
Pay and grades governed by Rajasthan Civil Services (Unification of Pay Scales) Rules and Schedules, 1950 framed under Article 309.
Assistant Secretary drew Rs. 250-25-400-E.B.-25-500 plus special pay Rs. 50/-. Deputy Secretary Rs. 500-25-700 plus special pay Rs. 100/-.

Rajasthan Secretariat Service Rules, 1954 framed under Article 309, effective 10th January 1955; appellant became member of R.S.S. holding Assistant Secretary post Rs. 250-25-400-EB-25-500 plus special pay Rs. 75/-.
Rajasthan Civil Services (Rationalisation of Pay Scales) Rules and Schedules, 1956 promulgated 25th May 1956 under Article 309.

Assistant Secretaries: Rs. 250-25-500-EB-25-750 plus special pay Rs. 75/-. Deputy Secretaries (selection posts): Rs. 500-30-740-EB-30-800-50-900 without special pay; on promotion, Rs. 500/- or minimum increase of Rs. 150/- on basic pay as Assistant Secretary, whichever higher.
Appellant appointed Deputy Secretary on 10th January 1959; drawing Rs. 475/- plus Rs. 75/- special pay as Assistant Secretary; pay fixed at Rs. 650/- (next higher stage above calculated Rs. 625/-).

Rajasthan Civil Services (Revised Pay) Rules, 1961 by Governor under proviso to Article 309: Assistant Secretary Rs. 360-25-560-30-590-EB-30-860-900 (merging special pay); Deputy Secretary Rs. 550-30-820-EB-30-850-50-1100.
R.A.S. under 1950 Rules: Deputy Secretary Rs. 500-25-700 plus Rs. 100/- special pay.
1956 Rules for R.A.S.: time scale Rs. 250-25-500-EB-25-750; selection grade Rs. 500-30-740-EB-30-800-50-900; special pay Rs. 150/- for Deputy Secretaries.
1961 Rules for R.A.S.: ordinary Rs. 285-25-510-EB-25-560-30-800; senior Rs. 550-30-820-EB-30-850-50-950; selection Rs. 650-50-1250; special pay Rs. 150/- for senior scale Deputy Secretaries.
1966 Rules for R.A.S.: regular Rs. 550-30-820-EB-30-850-50-1100 min Rs. 640/- plus Rs. 150/- special pay; selection grade plus Rs. 150/- special pay.

Appellant filed writ petition under Art. 226 in Rajasthan High Court (D.B. Civil Writ Petition No. 336 of 1964) claiming 'without special pay' in 1956 Rules invalid under Arts. 14 and 16; dismissed by judgment dated 18th November 1965.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the rules denying special pay to R.S.S. members as Deputy Secretaries, while granting it to R.A.S. members, violate Articles 14 and 16 of the Constitution.
Whether revised rules from time to time were less favourable to R.S.S. members compared to earlier rules.
Competence of Rajpramukh/Governor to promulgate revised rules under Article 309.

petitioner_arguments.text: Rules as applicable to R.S.S. on appointment as Deputy Secretaries less favourable than previous rules.
Discrimination: no special pay to R.S.S. but admissible to R.A.S. for same post, violating Arts. 14 and 16.
Post of Deputy Secretary equally arduous for R.S.S. as for R.A.S., so special pay should be granted per definition in Rule 73 Rajasthan Civil Service Rules 1951.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 73 Rajasthan Civil Service Rules, 1951; Article 309

court_reasoning.text: Revised rules ensured no prejudice to R.S.S. members compared to earlier rules; pay fixation gave minimum increase, scales higher.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No reduction in emoluments; revisions observed principle of non-prejudice.

court_reasoning.text: Rajpramukh/Governor competent under Article 309; rules not vitiated.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rules valid if considered against rights from time to time.

court_reasoning.text: R.S.S. and R.A.S. distinct services with different recruitment, qualifications, scales, posts; no equality required for same post from different services.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Equality only between members of same class; cited All India Station Masters case.

court_reasoning.text: R.S.S. get special higher grade for Deputy Secretary post; R.A.S. continue own scale plus special pay; different fixation methods.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No addition needed for R.S.S. beyond higher grade.

court_reasoning.text: Special pay per Rule 73 for arduous duties compared to prior post/service; for R.S.S., Deputy Secretary is selection post with higher grade already.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Special pay not inherent to post but relative to service cadre.

holdings.text: No violation of Articles 14 or 16; different services justify different pay treatment.
Revised rules not prejudicial or ultra vires Article 309.

precedents_cited.case_name: All India Station Masters and Assistant Station Masters Association Others v. General Manager, Central Railways and Others
precedents_cited.relevance: Equality of opportunity in promotion/employment only between members of same class of employees, not different classes.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kishori Mohanlal Bakshi v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: No discrimination under Art. 14 for different pay scales between Class I and II Income-tax Officers doing same work; equal pay for equal work not under Art. 14.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Framing of service rules; equality; writ jurisdiction.

statutes_cited.name: Rajasthan Civil Service Rules, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of special pay as addition for arduous duties etc.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed holding no violation of Articles 14 or 16 in denying special pay to R.S.S. members as Deputy Secretaries while granting to R.A.S. members; rules valid and non-discriminatory given distinct services.

key_quotes.text: "It is entirely wrong to think that every one, appointed to the same post, is entitled to claim that he must be paid identical emoluments as any other person appointed to the same post, disregarding the method of recruitment, or the source from which the Officer is drawn for appointment to that post."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle rejecting parity claim across services.

key_quotes.text: "Equality of opportunity in matters of promotion, must mean equality as between members of the same class of employees, and not equality between members of separate, independent classes."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quoting precedent to affirm no equality between different services.
